instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: No water damage.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: Or maybe I should be asking what causes the pulsing?

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: CPU Vcore also pulsing? Check if the rest of the rails are pulsing too. I doubt this "just" happened, ask the owner what happened.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
He claims he was using it and seen a wisp of smoke and it stopped working. I see zero evidence of water.

Other3V3, <SIGNAL>S4_X239</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S4_TPAD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> all pulse. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> pulses very very low. I think the VCORE was zero.

I see nothing burnt out. Tried new DCIN, and new battery as well.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: S5 should certainly not pulse! Is PPBUS stable?

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
I get pulsing off of <CAPACITOR>C1845</CAPACITOR>-1 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable 12.85-12.87.
On and off pulsing at <CAPACITOR>C8060</CAPACITOR>-1

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
PPBUS is too high, did you check on the correct side of the coil or on the fuse?
<SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
Have 12.8 on both sides of F7140. <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> is pulsing.
L7130 12.8 on both sides.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
12.8 is too high which is strange. Is your multimeter battery low? Check accuracy of the meter, PPBUS should never be higher than 12.58V.
If meter is OK then check sense resistor circuit for <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: Test Point 37 is 16.83.  Too high. Might be on to something.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
It's Fluke 15B+, I'll try new batteries.
New batteries is the same.

threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> 0.4ohm, <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> 10.0ohm, <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> 10.0ohm, <RESISTOR>R7111</RESISTOR> 19.0ohm, <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> 63.2ohm.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: See if the board does anything in SMC bypass mode. Hold power button and connect AC, hold for 5 sec. more and release and press again. PPBUS should come up at 12.23V now.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: It is 13.0V at <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>-1.

1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: I have no idea what you are doing, it should be lower in SMC bypass.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: Ha, ha. Sorry Duke. I have no idea either. I tried a couple of times. I even read for further directions online. I'll try it again and report back. I know its simple, but have no clue what I'm doing wrong : )

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: I first tried by shorting <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR>, and then assembled and tried that way too. First time I've heard about SMC Bypass. Found some things online about it. Never knew about it.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message:
With the battery plugged I get 12.86 on F7140-2 after SMC Bypass. Without the battery I get 12.56 and no pulsing at <RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR>-2. This is a new battery, and same thing with the old battery.
I am doing the SMC Bypass by shorting <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> with tweezers on each side. I am holding for 10 secs, then I plug in the power cord and wait 5 secs, then I release <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> and wait 2 secs, then I pinch <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> for 1 sec and release. Am I doing this wrong?

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: & this time I experimented by no battery holding <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> plug in battery then power, wait 10 secs, release, wait 5 secs, then hit <CAPACITOR>C4810</CAPACITOR> for 1 sec and getting 12.25 at F7140-2.

threads.title: 1502 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Pulsing at L7560
threads.message: I do get 5v on the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, I get .218v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, and nothing on the s4's.  So I am guessing that I need to check my <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rails?

threads.message: Out of ideas on this one besides to check for corrosion or missing components damage.
